item.title: An update on HTTPS certificate issues
item.description: For a little over a year now, this website has been enforcing HTTPS over both its www subdomain and the hjdskes.nl apex domain. These certificates are kindly provided automagically by GitHub in a partnership with Let’s Encrypt. In May, the certificate for my website expired. Expecting GitHub to be on top of this, at first I did not take any action. Some of you have reached out to me about the issue, which prompted me to contact GitHub to figure out why my certficate wasn’t being renewed.

item.title: This website is now HTTPS only again!
item.description: From today, my website enforces HTTPS again! Github Pages have been supporting HTTPS since June 2016, so when my website was reachable only through hjdskes.github.io I got all of that for free. In fact, because HTTPS is the future™, I enabled Github Pages’ enforce HTTPS feature in my website’s settings. Since June 28 2019, I have removed the apex domain (`https://hjdskes.nl`) from my DNS records. [It turns out that GitHub does not support HTTPS for both the apex domain and the www subdomain](https://help.

item.title: Update: deploying Hugo-generated websites on personal GitHub Pages
item.description: In my previous post I explained the workflow I use to update this website. It has never been particularly stable, and the process seemed far more complicated than it needed to be. This week I attempted to update the theme of this website. To pull in the theme’s files, I use git submodules. Apparently, this completely break git’s subtrees. I had enough of trying to maintain this complicated setup, so I started looking around for better ways.
